BIOS226
Notes
Rationale:

Advancements in computational biology are revolutionising the way biological data is analysed, enabling researchers to tackle complex challenges in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. BIOS226 – Informatics and Computational Biology provides students with the essential computational skills required to engage with modern bioinformatics research and applications.

This module is a critical component of the BSc Bioinformatics programme, equipping students with fundamental programming techniques, data pre-processing methods, and machine learning applications in biological contexts. Students will develop hands-on experience in analysing real-world datasets using high level coding languages, fostering both practical proficiency and problem-solving skills essential for careers in bioinformatics.

The module supports a research-connected teaching approach, ensuring students gain not only technical competencies but also an understanding of the ethical implications of computational methods in biological research. Case studies will highlight applications in disease classification, gene expression analysis, and biological system modelling, demonstrating the real-world impact of computational biology.

The development of BIOS226 has been informed by student feedback on existing bioinformatics and data analysis content, reflecting a growing demand for structured computational training within the curriculum. Informal discussions with students have highlighted the importance of practical coding experience and real-world dataset engagement, both of which are central to this module’s design.

BIOS226 is particularly relevant in the context of the global demand for bioinformatics expertise, driven by advances in personalised medicine, big data analytics, and artificial intelligence. By introducing students to bioinformatics methodologies early in their academic journey, this module lays the foundation for further study and professional development in interdisciplinary biological data analysis.

With a combination of lectures and practical workshops, students will develop the theoretical understanding and technical proficiency required to apply computational techniques effectively. As part of Liverpool’s world-class bioinformatics cluster, this module enhances students’ ability to contribute to cutting-edge research, preparing them for careers at the forefront of biological data science.

Overview

Overview
Computational biology is transforming the way scientists analyse biological data, providing powerful tools to address complex challenges in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. This module equips students with essential computational techniques used in bioinformatics, including data pre-processing, visualisation, and machine learning applications.

The module will be delivered through a combination of lectures and practical workshops. Workshops will provide hands-on experience, using programming tools such as Python or R to analyse datasets that emulate real research datasets. Lectures will offer a research-connected teaching approach, introducing the underlying principles and discussing the ethical considerations of computational techniques in biological research.

Students will engage with case studies that demonstrate how computational methods can be applied to predict disease classifications, analyse gene expression patterns, and model biological systems. Learning materials will be provided via the University’s Virtual Learning Environment (VLE), and assessments will be designed to evaluate both theoretical understanding and practical skills in bioinformatics.
Educational Aims
By the end of the module, students will be able to:

1) Select and apply suitable machine learning computational methods for analysing specific bioinformatics problems.

2) Pre-process and visualise biological datasets to prepare them for computational and machine learning applications.

3) Critically evaluate the performance of machine learning computational models using appropriate metrics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Computational biology is reshaping the field of bioinformatics, empowering scientists to address complex biological challenges in innovative ways. This module introduces students to the essential computational techniques applied to bioinformatics, from analysing gene expression patterns to predicting disease classifications and modelling and predicting biological systems that experiments alone fail to achieve.

Foundational skills in data pre-processing, visualisation, and machine learning techniques will be delivered through the context of real research conducted within the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences. Students will gain hands-on experience with programming tools like Python or R to implement bioinformatic workflows and models.

As the module progresses, students will apply the techniques they encounter to real-world bioinformatics challenges, exploring case studies in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. Students will also engage with discussions on the ethical considerations and limitations of computational techniques in biological research.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via a computational portfolio and a digital case study presentation.
Outline Syllabus
Syllabus Outline:

Part 1: Foundations (Weeks 1–5)

Students will develop core skills in computational bioinformatics, focusing on:

•Bioinformatics & Computational Biology. Key concepts, applications, and ethical considerations.
•Data Pre-Processing & Quality Control. Normalisation, missing data handling, and feature selection.
•Supervised Learning. Regression, classification, and applications in genomics and disease prediction.
•Unsupervised Learning. Clustering, dimensionality reduction (PCA, t-SNE).
•Model Evaluation. Performance metrics, cross-validation, and biological interpretation.

Part 2: Applications & Research (Weeks 6–11)

Students will apply machine learning techniques to real-world biological challenges, using research datasets. Topics include:

•Genomics & Transcriptomics. RNA-seq analysis, GWAS, and predictive modelling.
•Proteomics & Structural Biology. Protein interaction prediction and proteomic data analysis.
•Systems Biology & Network Analysis. Multi-omics integration and biological network modelling.

Student Engagement & Resources:

Students will be expected to engage with weekly learning resources (including lecture notes/pre- recordings, datasets, and coding exercises) via the Canvas VLE. Students will also be expected to engage with additional resources (research articles, data science platforms, e.g. Kaggle) to complete portfolio tasks.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures (mandatory attendance) will cover core curriculum topics, with research-focused lectures exploring current trends, including employability opportunities, in computational biology. These sessions aim to foster research-connected teaching, integrating cutting-edge topics and real-world applications that deepen students' understanding of the subject.

Active learning workshops (mandatory attendance) will focus on the practical application of theoretical concepts. These sessions will engage students in hands-on exercises, coding challenges, data analysis, and problem-solving activities based on real-world research scenarios. The workshops will help students build digital fluency, develop communication skills, and enhance their collaborative working abilities. By solving authentic problems, students will experience the intersection of theory and practice, reflecting the research-connected teaching of the module.

Additional weekly seminar sessions (non-mandatory attendance) will ad-hoc support to the cohort for troubleshooting and debugging code.
Student-directed learning will play a central role in the module, particularly through the completion of the computational portfolio. This will require students to engage with directed readings, critically analyse research articles, and solve computational problems using real datasets. This encourages independent learning and critical thinking, while developing essential skills in data analysis and problem-solving. The portfolio promotes self-reflection, as students continuously apply and evaluate their learning.

The module’s Teaching and learning methods meet the following hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework:

Research-Connected Teaching - Lectures will integrate current research, while workshops will involve hands-on data analysis, helping students to develop practical research skills and a deeper understanding of research processes.

Active Learning - Students will engage in problem-solving, group discussions, and data analysis. These activities will help them apply theory in practical situations, develop their skills, and get ongoing feedback from peers and the module team.

Graduate Attributes -

•Confidence: Students will build confidence through the completion of practical data/coding tasks and apply their learning to real-world problems.
•Digital Fluency: The module develops students’ digital skills through coding exercises and data analysis, preparing them for increasingly in-demand data science roles.
•Global Citizenship: Students will engage with international bioinformatics research, exploring global challenges and related ethical issues surrounding big data.
Assessment Strategy
This module's assessment strategy is designed to provide students with opportunities to apply computational biology techniques in real-world contexts, while encouraging critical reflection and effective communication. There are two assessed components:

Computational Portfolio:

The computational portfolio will fully document the student's solutions to workshop tasks and challenges, including numerical analyses derived from their unique datasets, tailored to relevant contexts. It will feature a detailed reflection on the use of Generative AI (GAI) tools, examining how they contributed to the analysis and learning process. This assessment aligns with the Authentic Assessment hallmark, offering a personalised, real-world data experience while promoting critical reflection on AI’s role in skills development.

Digital Case Study:

The Digital Case Study will involve creating a narrative video that communicates a real-world computational biology challenge, to a non-technical audience. Students will be permitted to use generative AI tools to assist in crafting an engaging script and video design. This task will encourage students to simplify complex computational biology concepts while showcasing their ability to communicate effectively. The case study also aligns with the Global Citizenship hallmark, addressing real-world issues and ensuring the content is accessible and relevant to a broad, diverse audience.

University of Liverpool · Semester 2 · Full-time

Bioinformatics and Computational Biology 2025-26

Module Code:BIOS226

In Programme:Bioinformatics BSc (Hons) 2024-25

BIOS226
Notes
Rationale:

Advancements in computational biology are revolutionising the way biological data is analysed, enabling researchers to tackle complex challenges in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. BIOS226 – Informatics and Computational Biology provides students with the essential computational skills required to engage with modern bioinformatics research and applications.

This module is a critical component of the BSc Bioinformatics programme, equipping students with fundamental programming techniques, data pre-processing methods, and machine learning applications in biological contexts. Students will develop hands-on experience in analysing real-world datasets using high level coding languages, fostering both practical proficiency and problem-solving skills essential for careers in bioinformatics.

The module supports a research-connected teaching approach, ensuring students gain not only technical competencies but also an understanding of the ethical implications of computational methods in biological research. Case studies will highlight applications in disease classification, gene expression analysis, and biological system modelling, demonstrating the real-world impact of computational biology.

The development of BIOS226 has been informed by student feedback on existing bioinformatics and data analysis content, reflecting a growing demand for structured computational training within the curriculum. Informal discussions with students have highlighted the importance of practical coding experience and real-world dataset engagement, both of which are central to this module’s design.

BIOS226 is particularly relevant in the context of the global demand for bioinformatics expertise, driven by advances in personalised medicine, big data analytics, and artificial intelligence. By introducing students to bioinformatics methodologies early in their academic journey, this module lays the foundation for further study and professional development in interdisciplinary biological data analysis.

With a combination of lectures and practical workshops, students will develop the theoretical understanding and technical proficiency required to apply computational techniques effectively. As part of Liverpool’s world-class bioinformatics cluster, this module enhances students’ ability to contribute to cutting-edge research, preparing them for careers at the forefront of biological data science.

Overview

Overview
Computational biology is transforming the way scientists analyse biological data, providing powerful tools to address complex challenges in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. This module equips students with essential computational techniques used in bioinformatics, including data pre-processing, visualisation, and machine learning applications.

The module will be delivered through a combination of lectures and practical workshops. Workshops will provide hands-on experience, using programming tools such as Python or R to analyse datasets that emulate real research datasets. Lectures will offer a research-connected teaching approach, introducing the underlying principles and discussing the ethical considerations of computational techniques in biological research.

Students will engage with case studies that demonstrate how computational methods can be applied to predict disease classifications, analyse gene expression patterns, and model biological systems. Learning materials will be provided via the University’s Virtual Learning Environment (VLE), and assessments will be designed to evaluate both theoretical understanding and practical skills in bioinformatics.
Educational Aims
By the end of the module, students will be able to:

1) Select and apply suitable machine learning computational methods for analysing specific bioinformatics problems.

2) Pre-process and visualise biological datasets to prepare them for computational and machine learning applications.

3) Critically evaluate the performance of machine learning computational models using appropriate metrics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Computational biology is reshaping the field of bioinformatics, empowering scientists to address complex biological challenges in innovative ways. This module introduces students to the essential computational techniques applied to bioinformatics, from analysing gene expression patterns to predicting disease classifications and modelling and predicting biological systems that experiments alone fail to achieve.

Foundational skills in data pre-processing, visualisation, and machine learning techniques will be delivered through the context of real research conducted within the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences. Students will gain hands-on experience with programming tools like Python or R to implement bioinformatic workflows and models.

As the module progresses, students will apply the techniques they encounter to real-world bioinformatics challenges, exploring case studies in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. Students will also engage with discussions on the ethical considerations and limitations of computational techniques in biological research.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via a computational portfolio and a digital case study presentation.
Outline Syllabus
Syllabus Outline:

Part 1: Foundations (Weeks 1–5)

Students will develop core skills in computational bioinformatics, focusing on:

•Bioinformatics & Computational Biology. Key concepts, applications, and ethical considerations.
•Data Pre-Processing & Quality Control. Normalisation, missing data handling, and feature selection.
•Supervised Learning. Regression, classification, and applications in genomics and disease prediction.
•Unsupervised Learning. Clustering, dimensionality reduction (PCA, t-SNE).
•Model Evaluation. Performance metrics, cross-validation, and biological interpretation.

Part 2: Applications & Research (Weeks 6–11)

Students will apply machine learning techniques to real-world biological challenges, using research datasets. Topics include:

•Genomics & Transcriptomics. RNA-seq analysis, GWAS, and predictive modelling.
•Proteomics & Structural Biology. Protein interaction prediction and proteomic data analysis.
•Systems Biology & Network Analysis. Multi-omics integration and biological network modelling.

Student Engagement & Resources:

Students will be expected to engage with weekly learning resources (including lecture notes/pre- recordings, datasets, and coding exercises) via the Canvas VLE. Students will also be expected to engage with additional resources (research articles, data science platforms, e.g. Kaggle) to complete portfolio tasks.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures (mandatory attendance) will cover core curriculum topics, with research-focused lectures exploring current trends, including employability opportunities, in computational biology. These sessions aim to foster research-connected teaching, integrating cutting-edge topics and real-world applications that deepen students' understanding of the subject.

Active learning workshops (mandatory attendance) will focus on the practical application of theoretical concepts. These sessions will engage students in hands-on exercises, coding challenges, data analysis, and problem-solving activities based on real-world research scenarios. The workshops will help students build digital fluency, develop communication skills, and enhance their collaborative working abilities. By solving authentic problems, students will experience the intersection of theory and practice, reflecting the research-connected teaching of the module.

Additional weekly seminar sessions (non-mandatory attendance) will ad-hoc support to the cohort for troubleshooting and debugging code.
Student-directed learning will play a central role in the module, particularly through the completion of the computational portfolio. This will require students to engage with directed readings, critically analyse research articles, and solve computational problems using real datasets. This encourages independent learning and critical thinking, while developing essential skills in data analysis and problem-solving. The portfolio promotes self-reflection, as students continuously apply and evaluate their learning.

The module’s Teaching and learning methods meet the following hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework:

Research-Connected Teaching - Lectures will integrate current research, while workshops will involve hands-on data analysis, helping students to develop practical research skills and a deeper understanding of research processes.

Active Learning - Students will engage in problem-solving, group discussions, and data analysis. These activities will help them apply theory in practical situations, develop their skills, and get ongoing feedback from peers and the module team.

Graduate Attributes -

•Confidence: Students will build confidence through the completion of practical data/coding tasks and apply their learning to real-world problems.
•Digital Fluency: The module develops students’ digital skills through coding exercises and data analysis, preparing them for increasingly in-demand data science roles.
•Global Citizenship: Students will engage with international bioinformatics research, exploring global challenges and related ethical issues surrounding big data.
Assessment Strategy
This module's assessment strategy is designed to provide students with opportunities to apply computational biology techniques in real-world contexts, while encouraging critical reflection and effective communication. There are two assessed components:

Computational Portfolio:

The computational portfolio will fully document the student's solutions to workshop tasks and challenges, including numerical analyses derived from their unique datasets, tailored to relevant contexts. It will feature a detailed reflection on the use of Generative AI (GAI) tools, examining how they contributed to the analysis and learning process. This assessment aligns with the Authentic Assessment hallmark, offering a personalised, real-world data experience while promoting critical reflection on AI’s role in skills development.

Digital Case Study:

The Digital Case Study will involve creating a narrative video that communicates a real-world computational biology challenge, to a non-technical audience. Students will be permitted to use generative AI tools to assist in crafting an engaging script and video design. This task will encourage students to simplify complex computational biology concepts while showcasing their ability to communicate effectively. The case study also aligns with the Global Citizenship hallmark, addressing real-world issues and ensuring the content is accessible and relevant to a broad, diverse audience.

Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 S1 Machine Learning Implementation – Apply supervised and unsupervised learning techniques (e.g., regression, classification, clustering) to analyse biological datasets.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2 · Full-time

University of Liverpool · Semester 2 · Full-time
 S3 Computational Modelling & Problem-Solving – Construct and analyse biological networks, simulate metabolic pathways (e.g., Flux Balance Analysis), and integrate multi-omics data while developing critical thinking and troubleshooting skills.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2 · Full-time
 S4 Scientific Communication & Collaboration – Effectively present findings through reports and presentations, work in interdisciplinary teams, and discuss ethical considerations in computational biology.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2 · Full-time

•Global Citizenship: Students will engage with international bioinformatics research, exploring global challenges and related ethical issues surrounding big data.
Assessment Strategy
This module's assessment strategy is designed to provide students with opportunities to apply computational biology techniques in real-world contexts, while encouraging critical reflection and effective communication. There are two assessed components:

Computational Portfolio:

The computational portfolio will fully document the student's solutions to workshop tasks and challenges, including numerical analyses derived from their unique datasets, tailored to relevant contexts. It will feature a detailed reflection on the use of Generative AI (GAI) tools, examining how they contributed to the analysis and learning process. This assessment aligns with the Authentic Assessment hallmark, offering a personalised, real-world data experience while promoting critical reflection on AI’s role in skills development.

Digital Case Study:

The Digital Case Study will involve creating a narrative video that communicates a real-world computational biology challenge, to a non-technical audience. Students will be permitted to use generative AI tools to assist in crafting an engaging script and video design. This task will encourage students to simplify complex computational biology concepts while showcasing their ability to communicate effectively. The case study also aligns with the Global Citizenship hallmark, addressing real-world issues and ensuring the content is accessible and relevant to a broad, diverse audience.

Notes
Rationale:

Advancements in computational biology are revolutionising the way biological data is analysed, enabling researchers to tackle complex challenges in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. BIOS226 – Informatics and Computational Biology provides students with the essential computational skills required to engage with modern bioinformatics research and applications.

This module is a critical component of the BSc Bioinformatics programme, equipping students with fundamental programming techniques, data pre-processing methods, and machine learning applications in biological contexts. Students will develop hands-on experience in analysing real-world datasets using high level coding languages, fostering both practical proficiency and problem-solving skills essential for careers in bioinformatics.

The module supports a research-connected teaching approach, ensuring students gain not only technical competencies but also an understanding of the ethical implications of computational methods in biological research. Case studies will highlight applications in disease classification, gene expression analysis, and biological system modelling, demonstrating the real-world impact of computational biology.

The development of BIOS226 has been informed by student feedback on existing bioinformatics and data analysis content, reflecting a growing demand for structured computational training within the curriculum. Informal discussions with students have highlighted the importance of practical coding experience and real-world dataset engagement, both of which are central to this module’s design.

BIOS226 is particularly relevant in the context of the global demand for bioinformatics expertise, driven by advances in personalised medicine, big data analytics, and artificial intelligence. By introducing students to bioinformatics methodologies early in their academic journey, this module lays the foundation for further study and professional development in interdisciplinary biological data analysis.

With a combination of lectures and practical workshops, students will develop the theoretical understanding and technical proficiency required to apply computational techniques effectively. As part of Liverpool’s world-class bioinformatics cluster, this module enhances students’ ability to contribute to cutting-edge research, preparing them for careers at the forefront of biological data science.

Overview

Overview
Computational biology is transforming the way scientists analyse biological data, providing powerful tools to address complex challenges in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. This module equips students with essential computational techniques used in bioinformatics, including data pre-processing, visualisation, and machine learning applications.

The module will be delivered through a combination of lectures and practical workshops. Workshops will provide hands-on experience, using programming tools such as Python or R to analyse datasets that emulate real research datasets. Lectures will offer a research-connected teaching approach, introducing the underlying principles and discussing the ethical considerations of computational techniques in biological research.

Students will engage with case studies that demonstrate how computational methods can be applied to predict disease classifications, analyse gene expression patterns, and model biological systems. Learning materials will be provided via the University’s Virtual Learning Environment (VLE), and assessments will be designed to evaluate both theoretical understanding and practical skills in bioinformatics.
Educational Aims
By the end of the module, students will be able to:

1) Select and apply suitable machine learning computational methods for analysing specific bioinformatics problems.

2) Pre-process and visualise biological datasets to prepare them for computational and machine learning applications.

3) Critically evaluate the performance of machine learning computational models using appropriate metrics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Computational biology is reshaping the field of bioinformatics, empowering scientists to address complex biological challenges in innovative ways. This module introduces students to the essential computational techniques applied to bioinformatics, from analysing gene expression patterns to predicting disease classifications and modelling and predicting biological systems that experiments alone fail to achieve.

Foundational skills in data pre-processing, visualisation, and machine learning techniques will be delivered through the context of real research conducted within the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences. Students will gain hands-on experience with programming tools like Python or R to implement bioinformatic workflows and models.

As the module progresses, students will apply the techniques they encounter to real-world bioinformatics challenges, exploring case studies in genomics, proteomics, and systems biology. Students will also engage with discussions on the ethical considerations and limitations of computational techniques in biological research.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The module will be assessed via a computational portfolio and a digital case study presentation.
Outline Syllabus
Syllabus Outline:

Part 1: Foundations (Weeks 1–5)

Students will develop core skills in computational bioinformatics, focusing on:

•Bioinformatics & Computational Biology. Key concepts, applications, and ethical considerations.
•Data Pre-Processing & Quality Control. Normalisation, missing data handling, and feature selection.
•Supervised Learning. Regression, classification, and applications in genomics and disease prediction.
•Unsupervised Learning. Clustering, dimensionality reduction (PCA, t-SNE).
•Model Evaluation. Performance metrics, cross-validation, and biological interpretation.

Part 2: Applications & Research (Weeks 6–11)

Students will apply machine learning techniques to real-world biological challenges, using research datasets. Topics include:

•Genomics & Transcriptomics. RNA-seq analysis, GWAS, and predictive modelling.
•Proteomics & Structural Biology. Protein interaction prediction and proteomic data analysis.
•Systems Biology & Network Analysis. Multi-omics integration and biological network modelling.

Student Engagement & Resources:

Students will be expected to engage with weekly learning resources (including lecture notes/pre- recordings, datasets, and coding exercises) via the Canvas VLE. Students will also be expected to engage with additional resources (research articles, data science platforms, e.g. Kaggle) to complete portfolio tasks.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Lectures (mandatory attendance) will cover core curriculum topics, with research-focused lectures exploring current trends, including employability opportunities, in computational biology. These sessions aim to foster research-connected teaching, integrating cutting-edge topics and real-world applications that deepen students' understanding of the subject.

Active learning workshops (mandatory attendance) will focus on the practical application of theoretical concepts. These sessions will engage students in hands-on exercises, coding challenges, data analysis, and problem-solving activities based on real-world research scenarios. The workshops will help students build digital fluency, develop communication skills, and enhance their collaborative working abilities. By solving authentic problems, students will experience the intersection of theory and practice, reflecting the research-connected teaching of the module.

Additional weekly seminar sessions (non-mandatory attendance) will ad-hoc support to the cohort for troubleshooting and debugging code.
Student-directed learning will play a central role in the module, particularly through the completion of the computational portfolio. This will require students to engage with directed readings, critically analyse research articles, and solve computational problems using real datasets. This encourages independent learning and critical thinking, while developing essential skills in data analysis and problem-solving. The portfolio promotes self-reflection, as students continuously apply and evaluate their learning.

The module’s Teaching and learning methods meet the following hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework:

Research-Connected Teaching - Lectures will integrate current research, while workshops will involve hands-on data analysis, helping students to develop practical research skills and a deeper understanding of research processes.

Active Learning - Students will engage in problem-solving, group discussions, and data analysis. These activities will help them apply theory in practical situations, develop their skills, and get ongoing feedback from peers and the module team.

Graduate Attributes -

•Confidence: Students will build confidence through the completion of practical data/coding tasks and apply their learning to real-world problems.
•Digital Fluency: The module develops students’ digital skills through coding exercises and data analysis, preparing them for increasingly in-demand data science roles.
•Global Citizenship: Students will engage with international bioinformatics research, exploring global challenges and related ethical issues surrounding big data.
Assessment Strategy
This module's assessment strategy is designed to provide students with opportunities to apply computational biology techniques in real-world contexts, while encouraging critical reflection and effective communication. There are two assessed components:

Computational Portfolio:

The computational portfolio will fully document the student's solutions to workshop tasks and challenges, including numerical analyses derived from their unique datasets, tailored to relevant contexts. It will feature a detailed reflection on the use of Generative AI (GAI) tools, examining how they contributed to the analysis and learning process. This assessment aligns with the Authentic Assessment hallmark, offering a personalised, real-world data experience while promoting critical reflection on AI’s role in skills development.

Digital Case Study:

The Digital Case Study will involve creating a narrative video that communicates a real-world computational biology challenge, to a non-technical audience. Students will be permitted to use generative AI tools to assist in crafting an engaging script and video design. This task will encourage students to simplify complex computational biology concepts while showcasing their ability to communicate effectively. The case study also aligns with the Global Citizenship hallmark, addressing real-world issues and ensuring the content is accessible and relevant to a broad, diverse audience.
